In many cases, "setsunai" is used to describe a bittersweet or nostalgic feeling that is tinged with sadness, but also includes a sense of fondness or joy for a past experience or person.

The idea of experiencing both happiness and sadness at the same time is a common theme in Japanese culture, and is reflected in expressions like "mono no aware" (物の哀れ), which refers to the bittersweet beauty of transience and the inevitability of change. This concept is closely tied to the feeling of "setsunai", and helps to explain why the emotion can contain elements of both happiness and sadness.

So, while the word "setsunai" is primarily used to describe feelings of sadness and heartache, it's not uncommon for it to also include traces of happiness or joy, especially in cases where the person is reflecting on a fond memory or a past experience that was special in some way.
